newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Ciampi sees rate cut as confidence grows.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Ciampi sees rate cut as confidence grows.

text.p: Italian Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi said on Tuesday he expected interest rates to fall as financial markets became convinced of the structural nature of lower inflation and healthier public accounts.

"Low inflation...has permitted past reductions in interest rates and those ahead, as markets become convinced that price stability is now a structural fact and not contingent on the wider Italian economy," Ciampi told the Senate (upper house).

Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio has come under intense pressure from the government, union leaders and industrialists to cut the 6.75 percent official discount rate, which he has left untouched since January despite steady falls in inflation.
Preliminary CPI data points to a 1.4-1.5 percent inflation rate in June, after 1.6 percent in May.

Ciampi, addressing the Senate at the end of a debate on the government's programme of economic forecasts for 1998-2000, also highlighted "...the choice of equilibrium in state accounts which we see today with...a three-year plan that will take us into the single currency by the front door."
"Being together with other countries in the euro means moving towards the same interest rates," he added.
